characters: DAMONE AND STACY IN THE JACUZZI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the outside parking lot it looks like an enormous beached whale. It is the prime hangout for all the teenagers in the area. Kids mill around the parking lot or stand by the mall entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three levels of stores underneath a massive fluorescent roof. Different music comes from each store. It looks seventies-modern, but already used and run-down. Groups of kids cruise the mall, eyeing each other and acting cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teenage waitresses in their peppermint pattie uniforms are rushing around, trying to keep up with their orders. A good-looking man in his mid-twenties enters and sits. He wears a plastic name tag that says: "Pacific Stereo Audio Consultant, RON JOHNSON." Two Swenson's Waitresses pass by with supreme indifference, and take their orders into the back kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he looks like Richard Gere. The two Waitresses discuss the issue at hand. One of them, Linda Barrett, is the seventeen year old, retired sex queen of Ridgemont High.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he looks like... Richard Gere. (Bruce Springsteen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see his cute little butt? A third waitress enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about C-19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll drop over and change the shakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, be cool, that's Stacy's section. Through the entrance, we see Stacy Hamilton. She is the fifteen-year-old trainee, sweet-looking with just the last traces of baby fat. She puts down a glass of water for Ron, spills some and mops it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's too old for Stacy, she hasn't even started high school yet. A flustered Stacy enters the back kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that guy's cute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a blow-dryed kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone else want to take his table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I fucked up. You can take it. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Stacy, it's your section and your man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take his order, look him in the eye and if he says anything remotely funny, laugh a lot. She fluffs up Stacy's hair and gently shoves her towards the door. Stacy reluctantly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy goes to Ron's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you working hard or hardly working? Stacy thinks it over, decides it's a joke and laughs (a little too late). Ron looks at her soulfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you could still be in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, everyone says that. He stares at her and she stares back uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get for you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your phone number? Stacy smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teenage boy stands in front of an in-mall theatre across from Swenson's. He wears a stiff over-sized tuxedo suit. He is Mark "The Rat" Ratner, a ticket taker on the job. Mike Damone, a transplanted Easterner, bops over from the record store, eyeing every girl he passes. He stops at the movie theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever look at those girls who work at Swenson's? They're beautiful. And I have to stand out here and watch them six nights a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should work for yourself. Two Junior High Kids spot Damone, walk up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the guy with the Van Halen tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want for something in the first ten rows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty bucks apiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those tickets were only twelve fifty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't buy 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to friend) All the other scalpers are sold out, Arnold. Damone reacts indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scalper? You call me a scalper? I perform a service, my friends. The service costs money. Now do you want the tickets or not? The Kids look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you can't go any lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are my special back-to-school prices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take 'em. Damone reaches inside his pants pocket for a wad of tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the other end of the mall is a neon-lit Carl's Jr. Hamburger Restaurant. If Swenson's was the warm up, this is the main attraction of the Ridgemont Mall. INT. CARL'S JR. Back-to-school banners hang from the walls. Many kids are lined up at the counters. In the middle of the kitchen, directing all the orders, is a seventeen year old named Brad. He moves confidently, observing the fryer, checking cup supply, and giving an affectionate squeeze to a pretty cashier named Lisa. She lets him kiss her, but only once. A teenage Customer shouts to Brad from the front counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Brad! I waited till you came on! I wanted your fries. Brad smiles, walks over to the fryer and discards the fries left from the previous shift. He shouts to the other employees as he puts in a new batch, "his" batch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need fifteen Superstars, David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Brad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of the fry orders! Just get me the Superstars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish sandwiches! Brad spots three surfers sitting in the dining area. None of them are wearing shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you guys! You had shirts on when you came in here.

dialogues.speaker: THE MAIN SURFER
dialogues.text: a bleary kid sitting at the head of the table. He runs a hand through his long, stringy blond hair. After a time, he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened to them, mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Spicoli. Why don't you just put your shirts back on? See the sign?

dialogues.speaker: HANDWRITTEN SIGN IN WINDOW
dialogues.text: that reads: "No Shirts, No Shoes, No Dice" INT. CARL'S JR. A store manager, Dennis Taylor, bustles up to Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just a couple of surfers with no shirts on. I took care of it, Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: SURFERS
dialogues.text: grumbling, putting shirts back on. It pains them. Dennis heads back to his office when he sees something in the trash bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you throw away those fries, Hamilton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were left over from the last shift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those were perfectly good fries, Hamilton.  (glares at Brad) Perfectly good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they weren't mine. Brad laughs, goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is closed and only a few janitors remain. Stacy and Linda walk through the large empty mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me his card.  (lovingly) 'Ron Johnson, Audio Consultant.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Should we buy a frame for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Linda, I haven't had a boyfriend all summer. You promised when I started working at the mall that my life would change... Do you think he'll call this week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Stace, you want to know about guys? I'll tell you. They're mostly chicken. Before I met Doug I chased after every guy I thought was cute. I thought if I gave out a vibe they'd get the message and call me up. Well, guess what? They don't call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called them. If I was sitting next to a guy and I wanted to sit closer, I'd sit closer. If I wanted to kiss him, I'd just do it. You want Ron Johnson? Grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. They pass a janitor cleaning graffiti that says: LINCOLN SURF NAZIS and MAGGOT LUST FOR THE DUST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face it. With some guys you have to make the first move. A lot of guys are just... wussies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy, what are you waiting for? You're fifteen. I did it when I was thirteen. It's no huge thing. It's just sex. If you don't, one of the other girls will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cute) He was hot, wasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I didn't have a fiance in Chicago, I'd go for it. A young Girl runs and catches up with Linda and Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) Are you Linda Barrett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Carrie Frazier from Toys 'R Us. Judy Hinton from May Company told me I could ask you something. Linda nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have this situation with my boyfriend, and I wanted to...  (looks at Stacy, then whispers in Linda's ear) Linda listens thoughtfully, then clicks into her "sex expert" mode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, are you over sixteen? The Girl nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what you want to do is go to the Free Clinic and tell the doctor that you have sex regularly  - several times a week -- and that you need Nornel One Plus Fifty's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they don't call my parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you're over sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks a lot, Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't let them talk you into a diaphragm either. The Girl thanks Linda again. Linda and Stacy get to the back exit of the mall and Linda uses a key to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I start high school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it. They exit the mall, into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see all the elements of the first day of school. The students carry new books, explore new lockers, begin to stake out their ground. Someone has taken the steel letters from the green vanguard out front. It reads: "IDG MON SENOR HI

dialogues.speaker: HO."
dialogues.text: The rest of Ridgemont High is covered with toilet paper. And a black spray paint message along the side of the front office building reads, "LINCOLN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad pulls into the Ridgemont High parking lot. He drives a beat-up, four-door model LTD sedan. Three friends wait for him near his parking space. They are dressed in the same golf caps with brand logos on the front like CAT, NATIONAL and CHAINSAW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cruising vessel! Hey -- Yooooo! Brad climbs out of his car and pats it admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six more payments, gentlemen. Brad joins his friends, and they walk towards the gymnasium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a shiny, new, blue Mustang whip into the parking lot. Students scatter from the parking space. Behind the wheel is football star Charles Jefferson. A huge, black kid. The halls at Ridgemont part for Charles Jefferson. Rat and Damone are in the parking lot. Damone surrounded by underclassmen (customers) selling tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that Mustang? U.C.L.A. gave Charles Jefferson that car when he was a sophomore. The underclassmen are impressed. They watch as Jefferson opens his car door and stands to his full height, over six-foot tall. He opens his trunk and pulls out no books, just a football duffel bag. He slowly walks by Damone, Rat and the underclassmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doing! That car looks great, Charles! Jefferson gives Damone a death glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't... fuck... with... it. He moves on. Damone resumes selling tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that's my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a clutching, smooching couple walk by. Cheerleader Cindy Carr and her boyfriend, Gregg Adams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Four Stoners (from Carl's Jr.) tumble out of a van in the parking lot. They head towards the gymnasium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by the A-B-C-D-E registration counter in the gymnasium, Brad waits to pick up his red ad card. He stands surrounded by his buddies. They nod vigorously at everything Brad says. As he talks, fellow students all say hello or pat him as they pass. One troubled-looking boy, Arnold, walks up to Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, can I talk to you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arnold. What's happening? Arnold speaks confidentially to Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, I really fuckin' hate McDonald's, man. Ever since they started in with the chicken, everything went downhill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to work at Carl's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, if you could swing something there, I'd do anything for you. I want to work with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can probably get you in there. Just let me talk to Dennis Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!! Brad notices Stacy and nods with complete inner cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... Where's Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone wants to know where Lisa is. How should I know where Lisa is? (to buddies) What am I gonna do? Now my little sister goes to the same high school. The party's over. (to Stacy) So who do you have first period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.S. History. Mr. Hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-yo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-yoooooooooo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) What's wrong with Mr. Hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... if you like 'Hawaii Five O.' You better get in class, Stacy. That's not the one to be late to. Stacy hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as soon as she is gone) Your sister is really turning into a fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see her in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-yooooooooooo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy barely slips in the door before the final attendance bell sounds. She finds a seat just as the teacher's cubicle door opens at the back of the classroom. A tall figure comes barreling down the aisle. He is Mr. Hand. The man makes a double-speed step to the door at the front of the class, kicks the door shut and locks it. The windows rattle in their frames. Stacy watches, wide-eyed, at her first high school class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha. My name is Mr. Hand. Mr. Hand writes his name on the green chalkboard before his class. Every letter is a small explosion of chalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost sweetly) I have but one question for you on our first morning 'together.'  (pause) Can you attend my class? Pakalo?... Understand?... History has proven us one basic fact. Man does not do anything that is not for his own good. It is for your own good that you attend my class. And if you can't make it... I can make you. An impatient knock begins at the front door of the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a twenty-question quiz every Friday. It will cover all the material we've dealt with during the week. There will be no make-up exams. It's important that you all have your Land of Truth and Liberty textbooks by Wednesday. At the latest. The knock continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your grade is the average of all your quizzes, plus the midterm and final, which counts for one-third. Got it? The mystery knocker tries a lazy calypso beat on the front door. No one in Mr. Hand's U.S. History class dares mention it, much less answer it. Stacy grips her desk with the tension of her first day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also. There will be no eating in this class. You get used to doing your own business on your own time. That's one demand I make. I don't like staying after class with you on detention. That's my time. I don't like wasting it. Just like you wouldn't want me to come to your house some evening and discuss U.S. History on your time. Pakalo? Hand finally turns, as if he has just noticed the sound at the door and opens the door an inch. Jeffrey Spicoli stands in the doorway, red eyes glistening. His long, blond hair is still wet and streaming down the back of his white peasant shirt. He grins, oblivious to such trivial matters as attendance bells. A Student sitting near Stacy turns to his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy has been stoned since the third grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm registered for this class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is U.S. History, right? I saw the globe in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appears enthralled) Really? Spicoli holds his red ad card up to the crack in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swinging door open) Oh, please. I get so lonely when that third attendance bell rings and I don't see all my kids here. Spicoli laughs. He is the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. This new schedule is totally confusing. Mr. Hand takes the red ad card and reads from it with utter fascination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Spicoli?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the name they gave me. Mr. Hand slowly tears the card into little pieces and sprinkles the pieces over his wastebasket. Spicoli watches in disbelief. His hands are frozen in the process of removing his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just ripped my card in two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, bud. What's your problem? Mr. Hand moves to within inches of Spicoli's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem at all. I think you know where the front office is. It takes a moment for the words to work their way out of Jeff Spicoli's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... dick. In the tense moment that follows, no one in the class is sure what might happen. Mr. Hand simply turns away from Jeff Spicoli as if he ceased to exist and coolly continues his lecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've taken the time to print up a complete schedule of class quizzes, and the chapters they cover. Please pass them back to the desks behind you... Hand begins passing out stacks of purple mimeographed sheets.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: all smelling the purple mimeographed sheets. Still standing in the doorway, hyperventilating with fifteen-year-old adrenalin, is Jeff Spicoli. After a time, he fishes a few bits of his ad card out of the wastebasket and huffs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's packed. The school's outdoor dining area is actually just a small courtyard lined with fast food machines and dominated by a large oak tree in the center. Standing at the center of lunch court, under the large oak tree, is Brad Hamilton and his golf-cap Buddies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear about the surfer in Mr. Hand's class? His Buddies shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told Hand to fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa!_ Brad sees another friend pass through lunch court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thompson! Brad waits for him to pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Thompson got canned at Bob's this summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They hacked his hours, so he quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making two eighty at Seven-Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man. (pause) They make you wear a fuckin' candy stripe suit over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor guy.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: near the outer rim of lunch court. Jeff Spicoli comes stumbling out into the daylight, surrounded by a small group of Ridgemont Stoners. Marijuana smoke billows out behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was so bitchin', mon. Everybody is talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motherfucker pissed me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. You don't have to take that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't take that shit. They all laugh, flip hair out of their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us again. What happened after he ripped up your ad card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called him a dick. And then I reached for his class notes, and I ripped 'em up. I said, 'Hey bud. Two can play this game.' The Stoners go wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you this. If he hassles me again, I can't be responsible for what happens... you know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's a fuckin' dick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. (pause) Gimme a dollar. One surfer digs out a dollar for Spicoli. They look out at lunch court, see it teeming with straight kids. They turn and walk towards the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: STACY AND LINDA
dialogues.text: as they walk onto lunch court. They take a seat on the outskirts of the area and watch all the students crowding onto the eating area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear some surfer pulled a knife on Mr. Hand this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! He just called him a dick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. People exaggerate so much at this school. The school couple, Cindy and Gregg walk by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Linda. God, you look so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, you guys. This is Stacy. Stacy, this is Gregg Adams and Cindy Carr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Stacy. Stacy smiles. Gregg and Cindy move on, repeating the same scene a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing that never changes... it's a cheerleader. Stacy turns to see a girl with short, black hair passing by, wearing tight black spandex pants, and dark lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda. That girl looks just like Pat Benatar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They watch her pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, there are three girls at Ridgemont who have cultivated the Pat Benatar look. Linda gestures out on lunch court.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER PAT BENATAR LOOK-ALIKE
dialogues.text: wearing pink spandex pants and short-cropped black hair with dark lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: STILL ANOTHER PAT BENATAR LOOK-ALIKE
dialogues.text: wearing blue spandex pants and short black hair. She stands a good distance away from the other two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of them talk to each other. Linda looks at them with bemusement but Stacy is wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think guys find that attractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, give me a break, Stacy. You're much prettier than them. They sit and eat their lunches. Linda has her perennial diet lunch of yogurt and raw vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but they look more sophisticated. You'd probably think they'd be better in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'better in bed.' You either do it or you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No there are variables that, like, I might not be good at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What variables?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) Like, you know, giving blow jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I never did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to it. She takes out a carrot stick and eases it down her throat. Stacv tries one but chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to practice a little first.  (feels her throat) Relax these muscles. Think of your throat as an open tunnel. The girls try sliding the carrot sticks down their throats without gagging.

dialogues.speaker: A BOY
dialogues.text: at the next table; sees them and points them out to his companions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens... don't laugh at me, but when a guy has an orgasm... you know, like, how much comes out. Stacy stops practicing and looks horrified. Linda laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding. About 10cc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enlightened) Oh! That's where that group got its name from. They continue practicing as the boys look on. Stacy manages to get almost a whole carrot down her throat to Linda's amazement. The group of boys break out in applause. Stacy looks very embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class is situated so that all students sit at Bunson burner tables lining the room. Pat is seated at one of the tables and Stacy takes a seat nearby; she looks at the ledge in front of her. It contains a pig embryo. She listens to the conversation next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you right now. I'm not going. I'll get sick or something. I'm not going into a room with a bunch of dead guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll go. It's part of the final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a Pat Benatar) Have you heard what they do? I'm serious. Have you heard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bodies are dissected, Mike, and Mr. Vargas pulls out parts of the dead body and holds them up. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean he reaches in and pulls this stuff out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearts, lungs, guts... Stacy strains to hear more, just as Mr. Vargas -- a diminutive man holding a coffee mug -- enters the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, everyone! I just switched to Sanka. I'm running a little slow today, so have a heart.

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT
dialogues.text: He is riveted on Stacy Hamilton, swooning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Stacy's room, a young girl's room with posters and frilly pillows. Stacy is in bed, and her Mother is just leaving the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep tight, Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mom. Her Mother shuts off the light, exits. Stacy pulls back the covers. She is fully dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the window to Stacy's room slide slowly open, and watch her slip outside. She hikes down a drainage pipe to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brown MG pulls up. Stacy jumps from the shadows and hops in. The car drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron sits behind the wheel, humming casually along to the music on his car stereo. Ron has on a light-brown leather jacket. He looks like a contestant for "The Dating Game."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little nervous) Thanks for picking me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. He speeds off, turning up the radio to sing along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Cuer-vo Gold, the fi-ine Columbian.' (eyes Stacy) You look nice tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. So do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you feel like going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Wherever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) The point sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her knowingly) All right, the point it is. We see Stacy's anxious face, as the car speeds up Ridgemont Drive, with music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy and Ron sit in the car, listening to music. The "point" is a natural lookout spot that lovers can "discover." It is behind the baseball field and dugout of Ridgemont High School. Stacy and Ron get out of the car and walk to the baseball dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit side-by-side. Above them, a single light bulb shines a very private fifty watts on things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thanks a lot. Silence. They look at each other, look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very warm out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is. It's very warm. I wonder how long it will last? Ron leans over and kisses Stacy lightly on the cheek. Stacy sits quietly for a moment, thinking, was that the first move? Then she lunges at Ron and kisses him square on the mouth. At first surprised, Ron then holds her there and kisses her in return. After a time, he breaks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really nineteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I am really nineteen. They continue making out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I better take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about those other guys you live with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean back to your home. But they make no moves in any direction. They continue making out. Ron begins unbuttoning her blouse and massaging Stacy's breasts. A moment later, he tugs at her pants. Awkwardly, she starts to help him. He tilts her backward onto the concrete dugout bench. They kiss feverishly, her hand pulling off her shoes, then her pants. Ron goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Is this your first time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STACY'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: as she feels a man enter her for the first time, we see the graffiti above her: Surf Nazis  Lincoln was here --  Sieg Heil  Led Zeppelin  Dan y Roberto (Disco Fags)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy is standing by her locker, twirling the combination. She is joined by Linda Barrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll always remember your first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me, do you like Ron? Is it serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Linda. It's just sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! That's my line! They both laugh and walk down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy arrives home. The Hamilton home has that anonymous prepackaged tract look, like many others in this lower-middle class neighborhood. Brad washes his car in the driveway and listens to the car radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom says to clean up the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friends use the pool. Your friends messed it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friends use the pool too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take out the garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't strain yourself. Stacy bristles, and heads inside the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furniture in the Hamilton living room looks like it was gleaned for a sale at Pic 'N Save. Through the living room, one can see a very small, kidney-shaped pool. Stacy checks an erasable telephone message sheet near the refrigerator. There are two names on it: BRAD/STACY. Brad's side is filled with messages. Stacy's is empty. She notices a summer bouquet floral arrangement. Stacy reads the attached note. It reads: "Memories of You, Ron Johnson." She quickly gathers it up and carries it back outside. She fans the door several times to dispel the odor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad! Have Mom or Dad seen this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not home yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, what would you say if I asked you to just put these flowers in the trunk of the Cruising Vessel and get rid of them at work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say... who the hell is Ron Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll explain everything later. Brad nods, as Stacy pushes the flowers into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone expertly fills two glasses three-quarters full of Kahlua, then adds a few drops of milk. Music is playing on a nearby speaker. Damone hands The Rat a drink and checks himself out in his mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that moustache coming in, Rat? There is only a hint of peach fuzz, but he grooms it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? You can almost press it out. Damone turns around. His friend is preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in love. Damone takes a sip of his drink, looks at The Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... are a wuss. Part wimp. Part pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean -- wuss? This girl is my exact type. It's her. Definitely her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) It's definitely your mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone, you gotta listen to me. Damone quits puttering around his room with the Kahlua and milk. He grabs a chair and straddles it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right... where did you see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in my biology class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get her number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never too soon! Girls decide how far to let you go in the first five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want me to do? Go up to this strange girl in my biology class and say, 'Hello! I'd like you to take your clothes off and jump on me?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) I would. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see it all now. This is going to be just like the girl you fell in love with at Fotomat this summer. You bought forty bucks of fuckin' film and you never even talked to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (woeful) You tell me, Mike. What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay.  (sighs, but loves it) Here's what you do. Damone gets up, moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You start from the second you walk into biology. Don't just walk... move across the room. He saunters over to the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to her. Let her know. Use your face. Use your body. Use everything. This is what I do. I just sent out the vibe and I have personally found that... girls do respond. Something happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course something happens. You put the vibe out to thirty million chicks, you know something's gonna happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the idea, Rat. That's The Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Attitude? The Attitude dictates that you don't care if she comes, stays, lays or prays. Whatever happens, your toes are still tappin'. When you are the cruelest and the coolest... then you have The Attitude. Damone knocks down the rest of his drink, and we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Brad operating at full throttle in the kitchen, and taking a moment to sneak a kiss with his girlfriend Lisa as she goes to the front counter to open up a cash register. She allows him only one kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were those flowers really for me, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much did they cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. She gives him a kiss... on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to the Point tonight. She pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to do at the Point? Brad shifts his weight, tries to find the right words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to do at the Point? God, Lisa, we've been going together almost two years, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad. I don't want to have to use sex as a tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tool? Tool for what? We've been going together almost two years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it here, Brad. Brad prepares to respond. He squints his eyes, prepares for a truly sizzling comeback, when Dennis Taylor, short and prematurely balding assistant manager of Carl's Jr., comes bustling out of his back office. He quickly surveys the situation in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton! You have fifteen double cheese to box! Lisa returns to her cashier post, leaving Brad's last words stalled in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Hamilton's cul-de-sac home. All the lights are off in the house at this hour. Except for Brad's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad is alone in his room. He's prone on his neatly made bed, reading a paperback book entitled Power With Class. On the wall of Brad's room is a large framed photo of a Carl's Jr. hamburger. Brad hears a muffled knock at his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in. Stacy walks into Brad's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for getting rid of those flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Who sent the flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just some guy I met at Swenson's. You don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care it you tell me or not. I got problems of my own. He begins pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything okay at work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Work is great. I kill at work. I don't even mind Mom and Dad making me pay rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to break up with Lisa, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing some thinking. It's my last school year. I'm a single, successful guy. I think I want my freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Because she won't sleep with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just guessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just need to give her some time. She's so nice, Brad. Everybody loves Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody loves Lisa. Everybody loves Lisa. But everybody doesn't have to be her boyfriend. Suddenly, Stacy pops the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Brad. Are you still a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I was just curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe yes. Maybe no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a virgin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your face did! They laugh. Then Brad turns serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe yes. Maybe no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that shit! I know you're still a virgin! Stacy smiles and stands up. She playfully slaps her brother on the arm and walks down the hallway to her room. We can see there is less frill and lace in Stacy's room. The junior high paperbacks are gone. There are no dolls in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda and Stacy walk past rows of cars. Stacy stops at a brown MG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... There's his car. I know he's at work tonight. He hasn't come into Swenson's since he called my house. My mother told him I was still at high school, after I told him I was nineteen. I guess I should tell him I'm fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare, you'll never hear from him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Doug care that you're seventeen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sees beyond that stuff to what the person inside is like. That's why I'm marrying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he ever calls again I'll say I'm eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy I am so glad to be through with all these games. They enter the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now several weeks into the school year. Mr. Hand is dropping test papers on desks like they are pieces of manure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C... D... F... F... F... three weeks we've been talking about the Platt Amendment. What are you people? On dope? A piece of legislation was introduced into Congress by Senator John Platt. It was passed in 1906. This amendment to our Constitution has a profound impact upon all of our daily liv.... Mr. Hand stops on a dime. He is like a champion hunting dog that has just picked up the scent. He scans the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Jeff Spicoli? There is silence in the U.S. history classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him earlier today near the 200 Building bathrooms. Is he still on campus? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone? One student sitting next to Stacy raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Desmond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him by the food machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just before class, sir... Mr. Hand snaps his fingers, Hawaii Five-O style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Bring him in. Desmond hustles out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this fascination with truancy? What is it that gets inside your heads? Mr. Hand begins to pace the aisles as he speaks. Occasionally, for emphasis, he bends down to lecture directly into the students' faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are other teachers in this school who look the other way at truants.  (points to attendance clip on the doorway) It's a little game that you both play. They pretend they don't see you, you pretend you don't ditch. Who pays the price later? You. Desmond returns to the room with a red-eyed Jeff Spicoli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Wait a minute! There's no birthday party for me here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Desmond. (to Spicoli) What's the reason for your truancy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't make it in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in top form) You mean, you couldn't? Or you wouldn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, mon. The food lines took forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food will be eaten on your time! (pause) Why are you continuously late for this class, Mr. Spicoli? Why do you shamelessly waste my time like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Mr. Hand appears mesmerized. He then turns and heads for the board. He writes in long, large letters as he slams the chalk into the green board. He writes: "I DON'T KNOW".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like that. He stands back and admires it. He turns randomly to Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like that, Miss Hamilton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like that too. 'I don't know'... that's nice. 'Mr. Hand, will I pass this class?' 'Gee, Mr. Spicoli, I don't know'. I like that. I think I'm going to leave your words on this board for all my classes to enjoy. Giving you full credit, of course, Mr. Spicoli. We hear the blare of the dismissal bell. Stacy and the other students get up to leave. Spicoli stays in place. He has just figured out a truly bitchin' comeback... and his mouth is forming the first word, when Mr. Hand cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go now. Hand turns back to his desk. The rest of the students have already left. Spicoli's audience is gone. He shrugs and lopes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Christmas time at the Ridgemont Mall. All three tiers are strung with neon lights, and we hear the sound of the bell-ringing Santas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy and Linda are enjoying a brief lull in the Christmas season madness. They sit at the sundae bar. Stacy looks forlorn, almost red-eyed, as she makes a sundae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to get used to working Christmas. People are always screaming and yelling... then they get home and they're all Christmasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Christmas brings out the worst in people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Ron hasn't called yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since November. Linda nods her head, always the coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy, it doesn't look good for the relationship. Stacy continues making her ice cream, slapping the scoops onto the stainless steel dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Don't you think it meant anything to him. Even if I am fifteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy. What does it matter? He's a stereo salesman. You want to marry him? You want to have kids with him? You want this guy to come home, fifty years old, and he's still got that little Pacific Stereo badge on? Come on.

dialogues.speaker: GREGG AND CINDY
dialogues.text: who are seated at a back table, feeding each other. Stacy looks at her finished sundae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should quit this job. I'm going to get so fat working here... nobody will ever take me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy. How many times do I have to tell you? You are really going to be beautiful... someday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. Linda punches Stacy lightly on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Ron Johnson? It's his loss. We follow Stacy, as she walks into the dining room to serve the sundae.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a group of buzz-cut young toughs, walking in formation, hunched over, sneering and wearing sleeveless U.S. Army fatigue jackets. None of these damaged-looking kids is over the age of fourteen. They pass to reveal this legend on their backs: LINCOLN SURF NAZIS. Angle on Mike Damone and Mark Ratner, who are standing by the upcoming concert list posted on the door to Wherehouse Records. Damone sees the Surf Nazis pass, turns to Mark Ratner, who is still wearing his Cinema Four jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The business is changing, Rat. I'll tell you, these kids today... they don't even listen to Aerosmith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear they all dress like that at Lincoln now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There used to be three or four of those guys. Now we see 'em every time we come to the mall. Damone is approached by a couple of young ticket Customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any Blue Oyster Cult tickets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Cult. I ate twenty-four pairs of Blue Oyster Cult tickets last time around. I was this close to working at 7-11. No Cult. Suddenly we see all ticket business stop. Damone and his customers see someone menacingly coming directly for them. The small crowd parts as Charles Jefferson, football duffel bag in hand, walks up. With him is a thick, tough, miniature version of himself. This is Little Charles. They both stop in front of Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after long look) When is Earth, Wind and Fire coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (respectfully) I'm really not sure. I haven't heard anything yet, but I'll let you know the second there is the slightest news, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking my little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. So that will be two tickets... All right. Fine, sir. Jefferson and L.C. push past the customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. He really lives here. I thought he just flew in for the football games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaining composure) Shit, he's my man. He knows where to come for tickets. Damone turns to The Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Rat. Are you ready for the moment of truth? The Rat adjusts his jacket, and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is immune to my charms. They walk together towards Swenson's, as The Rat drapes his aqua-blue Cinema Four jacket around his shoulders, like a French film director. Damone walks a few steps, then stops Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace the jacket. The Rat considers the suggestion, gets rid of the jacket. They continue towards Swenson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat pulls open the door to Swenson's. He walks toward the counter to Stacy Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. May I help you? The Rat feels the beginnings of cold panic, but barges through nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I have two questions. I was curious... His voice becomes a shade deeper. He begins to pull The Attitude together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do with the jackets people leave here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) We keep them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We keep them, in case the people come back. She reaches under the counter and pulls out a cardboard box with some rumbled jackets and other items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they are. You can look through it, if you want. The Rat chuckles to himself, struggling with The Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool. It would take too much time to go through all that stuff. I'll just pick up a new one. Stacy smiles. He's obviously awkward, and she likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your other question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My other question is... can-I-have your-phone-number-so-I-can-ask-you out-sometime? To The Rat's surprise, Stacy continues smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a pen? This one's out of ink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... yes. He pulls one out of his jacket pocket, gives it to her. Stacy writes her name and phone number on a scrap of paper and gives it to him. The Rat looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy. Nice to meet you, Stacy. My name is Mark Ratner. He sticks out his hand, and they shake. We see The Rat turn around and walk out of Swenson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat exits with ultimate cool. He sees Damone waiting just off to the side, talking to some girls. The Rat nods, gives him the thumbs-up. Damone returns the gesture. All-Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl's is happening tonight. There are lots of kids inside. We hear charging rock music -- "Girls Got Rhythm" by AC/DC -- coming from a radio in the back kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the bathroom, Brad Hamilton applies the Carl's scrub brush to a felt tip graffiti message near the mirror: I EAT BIG HAIRY PUSSY. He pauses and catches himself in the mirror. He adjusts his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking to mirror)  Lisa? I have something to tell you. Look, I'm a senior now. I'm a single, successful guy and I've got to be fair to myself. Lisa... I think I need my freedom. Brad pauses, looks at the mirror soulfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, don't do that... don't take it personally, okay? Please? I knew you'd understand, because... The bathroom door opens -- it's Arnold, the boy who Brad got a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad! I know you're on your break, but would you cover me on register three? Brad nods, exits:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad stands at the register. We see a prominent display over Brad's head: TRY OUR 100% GUARANTEED BREAKFAST. The last of many harried businessmen customers gets his breakfast order and takes his seat. Brad is joined by Dennis Taylor, the Assistant Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Clean that counter off Brad. Let's go. Play ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Dennis. Brad begins polishing the counter and Dennis Taylor returns to his office at the back of the kitchen. Brad watches him disappear behind the door that says: ASSISTANT MANAGER. As soon as Dennis disappears behind the door, the one Businessman in the place rises and returns to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) May I help you? The Businessman has short, curly brown hair. He speaks in a whine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. This is not the best breakfast I ever ate. The Businessman points to the huge display over Brad's head: TRY OUR 100% GUARANTEED BREAKFAST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want my money back. Brad begins searching under the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I believe you have to fill out a form. There's a pad right around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want my money back right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not the way it works, really. And you ate most of your food already, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that sign? It says 100% Money Back Guarantee. Do you know the meaning of the word 'guarantee'? Do they teach you that here? Give me my money back. Brad begins looking to the restroom. "Where's Arnold?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. But if you wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if talking to a kindergartner) Look. Just put your little hand back in the cash register and give me my $2.75 back. Okay?  (looks at name tag) Please, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. Just let me find the forms here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so tired. I am so tired of dealing with morons. How hard is it to... Brad looks up from under the counter. No amount of pay will make him take that kind of insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, if you don't shut up, I'm gonna kick 100% of your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manager!! "Bam!" The door to the Assistant Manager's office swings open, and Dennis comes hurtling out of the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir? Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet there's a problem! Your employee used profanity and threatened me with violence! I'm shocked, frankly. I've eaten here many times and I've always enjoyed the service -- until today! Angle on bathroom door as it opens and Arnold starts towards the register. He quickly sees the incident with the irate Businessman and ducks back inside the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I wanted was my money back for this breakfast. It was a little undercooked. And this young man threatened me. Now I plan to write a letter! I plan to... Dennis wheels around to Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you threaten this man or use profanity in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He insulted me first. He called me a moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you threaten this customer or use profanity in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired. Brad looks around, expecting his friends to defend him. Dave and Rich seem very occupied with their work. Brad is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Businessman) I'm very sorry this happened to you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Then Brad unhooks his fryer's apron and throws it on the counter. He grabs a backpack and walks out of the place. On the way, he bangs the bathroom door with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you had a hell of a piss, Arnold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives back in his room and locks the door. He yanks the burger picture off his wall, dumps it into the trash. Then he takes it back out of the trash and cracks the cardboard picture and plastic frame in half.

dialogues.speaker: DARKNESS
dialogues.text: We are in the middle of a deep, dark void. After a moment, a pinprick of light appears in the distance. We head towards the light. We are being led somewhere important. As we draw still closer, curtains suddenly part to reveal a wildly cheering studio audience. We hear the voice of Merv Griffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please give a warm welcome to... Jeff Spicoli! The Merv Griffin Show band begins playing a Merv Griffin Show version of AC/DC's "Highway to Hell". Someone hands Jeff Spicoli a microphone. He works the studio audience into a frenzy as he sings the words to "Highway to Hell": Merv Griffin show style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) 'Layin' ladies!                    Drinkin' wine!                 You gotta dollar -- You're a friend of mine!      Gettin' loose!                 Feelin' fine!                         You and me -- It's get down time! We're on the Highway to Hell!    The Highway to Hell!' Spicoli finishes up with a spectular pump. The audience goes wild as Merv Griffin greets him warmly, and guides Spicoli to his seat. Spicoli motions for the cheers to die down. Griffin is obviously happy to see him. He touches Spicoli's arm lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How've you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outrageous, Merv. Nice to be here. I feel great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to say... your eyes look a little red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been swimming, Merv. The audience howls. It's a famous Spicoli line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, Merv, everything is great. I was thinking about picking up some hash this weekend, maybe going up to the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) I wanted to talk a little bit about school, if I could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School. (sighs) School is no problem. All you have to do is go to get the grades. And if you know something, all you have to do is go about half the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How often do you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't go at all. The audience is howling again. He is Merv's favorite guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you brought a film clip with you. Do you want to set it up for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it pretty much speaks for itself. Peter, you want to run with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film clip begins. It is a mammoth wave cresting against the blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merv, this is the action down at Sunset Cliffs at about six in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fascinating. A tiny figure appears at the foot of the wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me, Merv. The audience gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to ride that wave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. We watch as Spicoli catches the perfect wave, and it hurtles him through a turquoise tube of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going through your mind right here, Jeff? The danger of it all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merv, I'm thinking... I've only got about four good hours of surfing left before these little clowns from junior high start showing up with their boogie boards. The audience is howling once again... when suddenly we hear the loud noise of a door opening, followed by a shrill voice. It is Spicoli's eight-year-old brother, Curtis. Jeff Spicoli's dream of glory evaporates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a messy trailer, part of a trailer park by the sea. Spicoli's area is small, but he has made it his own. The walls are covered with posters, almost all of them naked centerfolds. It is obvious Spicoli's parents are not welcome in his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad says you have to get up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. He groans, starts to struggle out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad says you're late again, you butthole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad says! Spicoli reaches over to the floor next to his bed. He pulls a snorkel from the mess, heaves it at the door and his little brother. It bounces off the wall and doesn't even hit Curtis, but the kid starts crying anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daaaaaaaad! Jeff threw a snorkel at me!!!!!! Spicoli gets out of bed, groans again, and kicks the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: celebrating the big game with rival Lincoln High School. We see Jeff Spicoli stumble from the direction of the parking lot. He heads into the gym, which is already full for a mandatory assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spicoli wanders into the assembly, takes a seat on a corner bleacher. He sits just below Brad Hamilton and Lisa. On podium in front of assembly, Cindy Carr and another cheerleader, Dina Phillips, are making a presentation before the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to say that we are not 'Spirit Bunnies' anymore. We always hated that name. It bugged the heck out of Dina and me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just such a put down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't call the Chess Club 'Checker Champs' or anything like that. We're going to go to everything this year, you guys. We're going to go to soccer, wrestling, basketball... everything. We know you've got a lot of spirit! Everybody -- riiiiiight? And we're gonna destroy Lincoln next week? Riiiiiiight?

dialogues.speaker: THE STUDENTS OF RIDGEMONT
dialogues.text: They don't respond.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF SPICOLI
dialogues.text: who is asleep in the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD AND LISA
dialogues.text: sitting nearby. We hear them over the drone of the assembly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I don't even want to see those guys from Carl's again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd apologize I think Dennis would take you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologize to that wimp? No way. Fuck Dennis Taylor.  They sit in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just glad we're still together, Lisa, because I need you this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Look, Brad, I've been trying to think of a way to tell you this. We're almost out of high school, this is our last year. I think we owe it to ourselves to be free, and meet some new people. Then, if we get back together, we'll know it's the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD'S FACE
dialogues.text: as he accepts the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I still want to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD'S FACE
dialogues.text: as it falls slack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to be going to every game this year. We just want the crowd to participate and we want spirit from every little person in this entire school. Allll-Riiiight? There is unenthusiastic, minor applause from the assembled students of Ridgemont High. Vice Principal Ray Connors, a tough-looking man with an H.R. Haldeman crew cut, approaches the podium. He has a sour look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, girls. People, don't forget, the big game is one week away. We'll see everybody back here on Monday and have a good weekend. For the first time during this assembly, there is a loud and hearty applause.

dialogues.speaker: A GRAINY HIGH SCHOOL FILM 57
dialogues.text: We are suddenly watching a movie shown on a class projection screen. We see footage of a serene, middle-class neighborhood -- as seen through the glass windshield of a car. Judging from the other vehicles parked on the street, the film is from the early Sixties. We hear the narrative voice of Desi Arnaz, speaking in his inimitable Latin accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving ess an important part of each and every one of our da-ily lives. Ees a responsibility like no o-ther and ess a matter of life and... A ball comes rolling out into the serene street. A small child runs out after it. The driving of our vehicle brakes, but not in time. The film freeze frames on the terrified face of a child about to be splattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death. There is a swell of dramatic music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have foun'... The Braking Point. The words flash on the screen and we hear a high school Driver's Training class groan in mock horror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES JEFFERSON AND BRAD HAMILTON
dialogues.text: who are seated in this class.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA AND STACY
dialogues.text: sitting together in the class. They are oblivious, lost in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of that guy who works at the theatre? You know, Mark Ratner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. What is he? Fifteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen. Linda looks nauseous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just watch out if he pulls up in a van, and then puts on a Led Zeppelin tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film returns to another serene street scene as seen through another front windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver here has had jus' two drinks. Two drinks at the home of a frien'. We hear the very-present sounds of Driver's Training students.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's fucked-up, Ricky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They guys a drunk, Ricky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And although this driver thinks he ees drivin' well, he may be 'doing okay, but he forgets to per-ceive what ees real goin' on... In the film, another car comes barreling from the left, running a stop sign and exploding into the side of the two-drink goner. In the class, the Driver's Training students are howling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot is full. Kids and shoppers stream through the entrance in groups of all sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three levels are teeming with kids.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIDEO PINBALL ARCADE
dialogues.text: where we see Jeff Spicoli manning the Missile Command machine. Spicoli wears a red bandana across his forehead. A cigarette dangles from his mouth. He is surrounded by a fleet of young surfers who listen to him with reverence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be noble. Be aggressive. The thing about Missile Command is to decimate before you can be decimated. Just like in real life.  The youngsters hang on every word of the sage advice.

dialogues.speaker: A GANG OF SURF NAZIS
dialogues.text: walking in formation.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DAMONE AND MARK RATNER
dialogues.text: walking the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out, Rat. The Surf Nazis... out for a Sunday stroll. Damone and The Rat walk on. The Rat is barely interested. He appears deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I say after she gets in the car? Damone, obviously in his element here at the mall, stops to flash a winning smile at a well-built older housewife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, Rat. What you need is my special Five Point Plan. As he talks, Damone passes a Country Farms shop. He plucks a free sample of cheese and sausage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Damone. I need real help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Men have died trying to obtain this information. I will give it to you for free. The Rat and Damone continue on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Tell me. What's the Five Point Plan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Pay attention. The Rat nods, always the student, as they pass a Wherehouse Record store. Damone stops right in front of a seductively posed life-sized cardboard stand-up of Debbie Harry, the alluring rock singer. Damone begins his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, Rat... never let on how much you like a girl. Damone turns to the cardboard cutout of Debbie Harry to demonstrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disinterested) Oh. Hi. (turns back to The Rat) ) Two. Always call the shots. He turns to Debbie Harry, who looks on with an inviting cardboard smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss me. (to The Rat) Three. Act like wherever you are, that's the place to be. (to Debbie Harry; debonair) ) Isn't this great? (to The Rat) Four. When ordering food, find out what she wants and then order for both of you... it's a classy move. (to Debbie Harry; Cary Grant) And the lady will have... (to The Rat) Five. And this is most important. When you get down to making out, whenever possible, put on the first side of Led Zeppelin IV. (to Debbie Harry; seductive) Why don't you put this tape on? It sounds great in the back of my van... why don't we listen from there?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE HARRY
dialogues.text: with the same inviting smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is how you talk to a girl, Rat. Voila. You can't miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've got it. Once I get going, I'll be okay. But... how do I get started? I mean, I hardly know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wuss. It's no problem. One person says something to the other and that's how it starts... Standing there in the front of the Wherehouse, The Rat nods his head and smiles. He's finally beginning to understand, and we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see The Rat behind the wheel of a green Volvo. Stacy sits beside him. They are driving the streets of Ridgemont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. The Big Date. "Led Zeppelin IV" is on the car stereo of his sister's van. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming to get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rounds the corner of Luna Street, off the neon fast-food stand that is Ridgemont Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet another silence has fallen. Then, after a time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nice car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's my sister's. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have Mrs. George for English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into the parking lot of a steak and lobster house called The Atlantis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey at Cinema Four said this is a pretty good restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard that, too. The Rat finds a parking spot near the back of the lot, grateful that the long silence is over. He walks with Stacy to the front of The Atlantis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat and Stacy are escorted by the host to a nearby table. They are given large wooden menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll have the Seafood Salad Special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. The Rat leans back in the booth. He is starting to feel in control now. Then something hits him. The panic sweeps across his face. Slowly, The Rat reaches back to check his wallet. It's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) Oh yeah. Cool. Cool was the name of the game. Stay cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I excuse myself for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Just as The Rat is about to get up, the Waitress approaches the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready to order here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... sure.  (settles back down) She will have the Seafood Salad Special. And I will have... the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks. The Rat gets back up again, looking paler by the minute. He excuses himself and walks over to the pay phone by the Atlantis toilets. The Rat dials a number. Damone answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sitting in a chair, leaning onto the back two legs, watching television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone. It's Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark. What happened to your date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happening right now. I'm here at the Atlantis. Everything's fine except... I left my wallet at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go home and get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's too late. The food is coming and everything. Damone, I've got to ask you this favor, and I'll never ask you for anything again in this lifetime or any other. Will you please borrow your mom's car, go by my house, get my wallet, and meet me back here? There is silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone, are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (world-weary sigh) I'm really pretty busy...

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE'S TELEVISION
dialogues.text: as we see the flickering images of Leave It To Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat hangs up, mildly relieved, and returns to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat and Stacy have finished the meal, and desert.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHECK
dialogues.text: as it sits in a little tray before The Rat. The Waitress approaches the table. It is clear she wants to make room for other customers and bigger tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure there's nothing else I can bring you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have one more Coke... Do you want another Coke, Stacy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzical) ) Sure. I'll... have another Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
