dialogues.text: Two more Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Two... more... Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: as Mike Damone finally walks in. Damone looks over the diners, then feigns great surprise when he sees The Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mark. Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone! You come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come for the seafood. It's great! Hey... you know what, Mark? I found your wallet the other day. You want it back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I've been looking for that thing! Hey, Damone, have you met Stacy Hamilton? Stacy, this is Mike Damone. Stacy smiles politely, with the slightest sparkle in her eye, as the Waitress returns with the two Cokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've gotta be running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. See ya.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: looking strangely at the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Damone leaves. The Rat takes a few quick gulps of Coke, and gets up to pay the bill. As he moves out of camera range, we see the strange look on the faces of waitresses and diners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rat pulls up to Stacy's house in the cul-de sac. He stares straight ahead, like a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a really nice time tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too. I'm real sorry someone broke in and stole your tape deck. The Rat nods glumly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought it would happen at The Atlantis. Jeez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to come inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't your parents asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're away for the weekend. Brad and I are watching the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. I'll come in. We see a confused but interested look on The Rat's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in the front door. The Rat stands uncomfortably in the doorway to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Probably out. Want something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to change real quick. I hope you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw. I don't mind. Stacy turns her back and pulls up her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you unzip me?

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT'S FACE
dialogues.text: as the wheels inside his mind start to spin. This can't be what it seems. He unzips Stacy, past her bra, down to the small of her back. It's the first time he's ever done anything like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks! She walks down the hall to her room, easing out of her dress as she walks. She leaves the door to her room open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can come in, if you want!

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT'S FACE
dialogues.text: He is completely unsure of himself, as he begins to walk down the hall. His heart pounds into his throat. He turns the corner and steps into Stacy's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy stands there, looking gorgeous in an almost seethrough white robe. The Rat pretends not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... pretty nice house you've got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. So...  (puts hands on hips) What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT'S FACE
dialogues.text: as he struggles with the memory of Damone's words. "Always call the shots."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see some pictures? I kept a lot of scrapbooks and pictures and stuff from junior high. How stupid, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Stacy goes to her closet, reaches up to grab the books from the top shelf. The Rat watches her robe slip up her legs. Then she sits down next to him. Her knee grazes his. It is almost too much for The Rat. Go for it. We see The Rat struggle with the action of putting his arm around her. He almost does, but then reacts as she says suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me in the eighth grade. Did you have Mr. Deegan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking pained) Oh, yeah. I had Mr. Deegan. Her knee grazes him again. Does she expect something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Stacy, I want you to know that... The Rat struggles. Try as he might, he can't seem to cross the line. He can't make his move. He is woeful as he completes the sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I've got to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really have to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's getting kind of late. Suddenly, The Rat is seized with ambition. He reaches one hand around her right shoulder and plants the other hand directly on her left breast. It looks something like a wrestling hold. The Rat looks at Stacy. Stacy looks back at The Rat. The Rat is absolutely frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it is getting late, Mark. She shrugs him off, walks him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see The Rat's forlorn face as he trudges towards his car. He stops. He takes a breath -- it wasn't that late, he really didn't want to leave. The Rat turns and begins walking back up the Hamilton steps. Just as he does so, Stacy's bedroom light clicks off. It was too late. He kicks at his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You blew it, asshole. Behind him, recklessly speeding towards Ridgemont Drive, is Charles Jefferson's blue Mustang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Spicoli is behind the wheel. Sitting next to him is Little Charles, "L.C.", Jefferson's younger brother. They're smoking grass and holding Lowenbrau beers in between their legs. The radio is blasting the music of Rick James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, slow down. This is my brother's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't hassle it. They speed off down Ridgemont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen the new Playboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw. Any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne Somers' tits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like sex. Spicoli sees something in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your beer down, L.C., I think it's a cop. Spicoli slows down. The car behind him slows down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a cop. He's definitely cruising me at busting distance. The high beams switch on behind Spicoli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this guy doing? The car behind Spicoli then advances to the point where it is now almost touching the blue Mustang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this guy doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't no cop. The mystery car bumps them lightly from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! He's gonna scratch my brother's car! The two boys start yelling. High beams fill the Mustang with bright light and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then mystery car pulls back, then up alongside Spicoli and L.C. on the left. We hear the music on the radio of George Thoroughgood's "Ride On, Josephine".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bunch of Jocks in a Granada!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're fuckin' with us. The drivers of the two cars eye each others. Then the Granada begins inching over, trying to force Spicoli off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother's car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Die, Granada Jocks! Spicoli guns ahead, in a real bullet move, and easily overtakes the Granada. Spicoli is proud of himself. He checks himself out in the rearview and turns to L.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you roll your window up, L.C.? It's messing my hair. Spicoli pulls way ahead of the Granada, while L.C. rolls his window up. Spicoli looks over to L.C. and smiles wickedly. Now Spicoli wants to show off. He pushes the pedal to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just missed the turnoff to the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the thing I love about Mustangs? The steering wheel. Spicoli fingers the bubbles in the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a genuine Mustang steering wheel, you can negotiate a hairpin turn with ease, my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the word "ease", Spicoli curls his finger into one of the Mustang steering wheel bubbles and whips it clockwise. The idea is to turn off onto a side street and head back to the party. But instead, at the moment of the hairpin turn, L.C. is attempting to switch the radio station. Spicoli crooks his finger farther into the bubble than he expected. The car swings in a complete circle, a circle that includes a bright yellow fire hydrant. The hydrant rips the side of the car open like a can of tuna. There is a silent moment of terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? There is silence. Outside the smashed car, the Granada Jocks pass Spicoli and L.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck youuuuuuuuuu! Then L.C. stirs and utters his first words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is going to kill us. He's gonna kill you and then he's gonna kill me. He's gonna kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be glad you're all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is gonna shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make up your mind. Is he gonna shit, or is he gonna kill us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First he's gonna shit. And then he's gonna kill us..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just relax, mon? He's not gonna kill us. My father is a television repairman. He's got all kinds of tools. I can fix-this car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't fix this car, Spicoli.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLUE MUSTANG
dialogues.text: waffled and mangled. It is just inches away from scrap iron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: as we see Ridgemont High gearing up for its big Homecoming Game against Lincoln. We see a series of shots of kids talking about it, wagering on the chances of a Ridgemont victory. We see the many signs and placards all over school, proclaiming Ridgemont revenge. We see students lining up to vote for Homecoming King and Queen in the gymnasium. It is the most spirit that Ridgemont has shown this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the back of the parking lot, we see a crowd around the flagpole. A group of kids are staring at something. They sadly shake their heads at the sight, as if they are witnessing a funeral. As we draw closer, we see the center of commotion. It is an ugly sight. Someone had wrecked Charles Jefferson's Blue Scholarship Mustang and welded it to the flagpole. Spray-painted on the side was the message: LINCOLN SURF PUNKS RULE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ridgemont football bleachers are full of cheering students. We see the same basic groups from lunch court, and many more. The cheerleaders are on the field -- Cindy Carr, Dina Phillips and company -- and their cheerleader "husbands" sit directly in front of them in the stands. Linda and Stacy sit in the bleachers with some of the Swenson's girls. The Rat and Damone sit several rows above them, watching. The teachers sit together in another section.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD HAMILTON
dialogues.text: who is again sitting alone in the bleachers. Watching. Several old lunch court friends pass by, on their way to the concession area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Brad! How's going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you working?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish and chips place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a fish and chips place. Brad says nothing more. The students look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be seeing you, Brad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullen) Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is cheering the amazing game on the field. Charles Jefferson is poised on the offensive line. He mutters a string of obscenities at the opposing Lincoln player. The ball is snapped, and Charles Jefferson comes directly at the player with both elbows up and angled to hit inside his helmet. The Lincoln player is hit and keels over. Charles Jefferson sets up for another play. The ball is snapped. Ka-boom. Down falls another Lincoln player. Jefferson doesn't know who it was who wrecked his Mustang, but he wasn't about to spare any of them. There is pure madness in his eyes. It has taken him over. The Ridgemont points rack up. Jefferson is single handedly maiming Lincoln for Homecoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Jeff Spicoli and L.C. sitting calmly in the bleachers, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we may have gotten away clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The half-time gun fires and the score is 36-7... Ridgemont. Even the Ridgemont players steer clear of Charles Jefferson as they return to their locker room.

dialogues.speaker: WEEKS LATER
dialogues.text: Linda and Stacy are sitting by the pool, dressed in string tie bathing suits. They are listening to the music of Tom Petty's "Breakdown" playing on the living room stereo. Linda luxuriously applies suntan lotion to her chest and legs, in long and writhing strokes. Stacy reads a book. It's called Total Orgasm. Several beats pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent a letter to Doug today. I'll be so glad when he gets out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (engrossed in book) You really ought to look at this, Linda. There's a drawing on every page... and all these quizzes. It's like school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you put your mother's secret book back? Linda continues regally applying lotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this... 'What are your mate's three most erogenous zones?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (automatic) Okay, penis, that's one, balls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't penis and balls be the same category?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Probably penis, mouth and neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Here's another one. 'The most satisfactory lovemaking occurs when your mate climaxes first, you climax first, you and your mate climax together?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climax together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that ever happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But it's a nice idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this ... it says 'Most women derive pleasure from sex, but they don't have real orgasms.' Linda stops applying lotion, considers that thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... they obviously don't know about Doug. They laugh. Linda resumes applying the lotion. Stacy continues reading the book. A couple of beats pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does Doug take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Thirty to forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) What's Doug do in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works for the airline. He'll be out here. You'll meet him. Stacy looks at Linda, almost disbelieving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistful) He's no high school boy. There is a noise by the side fence leading into the Hamiltons' backyard. It is Mark Ratner and Mike Damone. They are already wearing swimsuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! We came over to help you with Math homework!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. We figured you needed the help. On such a hot day. Stacy quickly stashes the book in a stack of towels beside her. She leans over to Linda and speaks confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're both virgins. Stacy smiles, gets up and goes over to the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask for any help. Did you, Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's exactly why I brought some Wisk for the jacuzzi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-kay, you guys can come swimming. But you have to leave as soon as my Mom gets home. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Damone yells "banzai!" and dives into the small pool. At one end of the pool is the jacuzzi, which is separated by a tile wall. Damone has already poured the Wisk into the jacuzzi, and the detergent has created a huge bubble bath effect. Damone surfaces and flips into the jacuzzi. Stacy, looking great in a green bikini, sits kicking her legs by the side of the pool. Linda stands on the board. She is poised to dive. The Rat treads water and stares at both girls. Inside the Hamilton living room, the family stereo plays the music of Deep Purple's "Woman From Tokyo".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Linda! I'll judge your dive. I'm a champion diver myself. Brad arrives home by the side gate and slams it behind him. He is home from a bad day at work. He walks out onto the patio and stands with his hands on his hips. For the first time, our former campus hero looks absurd. He is still in his uniform from Captain Kidd Fish and Chips -- it is a blue and white striped Pirates of the Caribbean outfit, complete with black plastic sword at the side, and a ridiculously large Ponce de Leon-esque hat. Brad carries the hat under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Mom know you have company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just Linda. And Mark from school. Brad ignores the underclassmen, and notices Linda on the board in her maroon bikini. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Linda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you guys, keep it down. I've got some work to do upstairs. Brad turns and heads back inside. He is just out of earshot when they begin talking about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he hardly even talks anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. He hates to have to wear uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Stacy breaks the spell by jumping into the water, surfacing, and flipping over the tile wall into the Jacuzzi. She sits next to Damone, looking mischievous.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE AND STACY IN THE JACUZZI
dialogues.text: talking while the others are at the other end of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT
dialogues.text: casually catching sight of them together from the other side of the pool. We can read the emotions on The Rat's face. He is still taken with Stacy, but his big moment for her appears to have passed.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE AND STACY IN THE JACUZZI
dialogues.text: as they talk. Underneath the water, her leg accidentally knocks against his. Then he feels her continue. Damone feels Stacy's cool hand on his inner thigh. Moving upwards, stopping just short of the bulge in his trunks.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE'S FACE
dialogues.text: as it loosens and quivers just the slightest bit. This is uncharted territory, even for Mr. Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: who is now sunning herself by the side of the pool. She rubs her legs against each other, slowly, enjoying the hot afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: who is watching Linda from the window in his room. We see him from behind, peeking out the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: who smiles at Damone and flips back into the pool with a splash. Damone steals a look down at his swimsuit. He's popped a big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you get up and do a dive, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE'S FACE
dialogues.text: and we know he can't get out of the water yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so. Not right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicken! Linda, for one, loses interest quickly. Standing by the side of the pool, she jams a finger in her ear and wiggles it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy! I've got water in my ears. Do you have any Q-Tips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I don't think so. Better look in the house. Linda towels off and heads back inside the Hamilton house. She knows how to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Brad's room. The Carl's burger picture on the wall is conspicuously missing. There is music playing from his stereo -- Pink Floyd's "You and Me". We see Brad. He is kneeling on the bathroom floor, his back to us. His green T-shirt is on, his underwear in a pile on the floor behind him. His arm is pumping slowly. Brad is jacking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It features Linda Barrett, just as she stood on the diving board a moment ago. She is gorgeous. Her breasts seem even bigger than usual. Her nipples are hard, poking through the film maroon string bikini. Water rolls slowly down her cheeks, into the corners of her mouth. Her lips are parted slightly. Her eyes are filled with desire as she says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Brad. (pause) You know how cute I always thought you were. I think you're so sexy. Will you come to me?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD IN DAYDREAM
dialogues.text: in a nice shirt, his hair combed back and looking great. He walks to Linda. She reaches out and grabs him for a kiss, pulling him close. Then she pushes him away, so he can watch as she carefully unstraps the top of her bathing suit. The incredible Linda Barrett's breasts fall loose. She takes Brad's hands and places them on her, as she begins unbuttoning his shirt. They are just about to fall into passionate lovemaking when we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Brad! Do you have any Q-Ti... The daydream evaporates and we see real life again with an...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA'S FACE
dialogues.text: in the doorway of Brad's bathroom as she watches the sight before her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: trying to cover himself and act nonchalant and keep his back turned at the same time. The words barely escape his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait just a... minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't know anybody was in here. Linda turns and goes immediately, as if she wants to forget what she saw as quickly as possible. She closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: still kneeling. It had all happened so quickly, so fast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't anybody fuckin' knock anymore? He slams the toilet seat down and we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third attendance bell rings, and Mr. Hand strides to the front of the class. He locks the door. Then he takes the front of the class and notices something very different.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF SPICOLI
dialogues.text: bright and clear-eyed, sitting in the front row. His hands are clasped in front of him on the desk. His textbook is open to the proper page. Mr. Hand is suspicious, but continues with class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in 1898, Spain owned Cuba. Outright. Think about it. Cuba, owned by a disorganized parliament 4,000 miles away. Cubans were in a constant state of revolt. Mr. Hand begins pacing the aisles as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 1904, the United States decided to throw a little weight around, and... There is a brief, sharp knock at the door. Mr. Hand whips his head around, like McGarrett. He approaches the door like a cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweet voice) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pizza, sir! Hand swings the door open, out of curiosity. In walks a young Man in a Mr. Pizza delivery shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, who had the double cheese sausage and bologna? Jeff Spicoli speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. The Delivery Man takes the pizza, sets it on the desk, as Spicoli whips out some crumpled dollars. Then he produces yet another crumpled dollar, and presses it into the Delivery Man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, my man. The Delivery Man thanks him warmly, just as Mr. Hand rages into the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I hallucinating here? Just what in the hell do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learning about Cuba. Having some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Spicoli, you're on dangerous ground here. You're causing a major disturbance in my class and on my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool and urbane) I've been thinking about this, Mr. Hand. If I'm here... and you're here... doesn't that make it our time? Mr. Hand is so furious he's almost shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I thought I'd order us a pizza. Just leave me a lot of bologna... Mr. Hand snatches up the pizza, and starts to throw it in the wastebasket. Then he thinks better, and heads for the door. He opens it just as a gang of young Stoners walk past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally! Mr. Hand pushes the pizza into their hands and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better save some for me, you swine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, my friend. I'll see you for a two-hour detention every afternoon this week. Spicoli eases back in his chair, shrugs. It was a good idea at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad Hamilton, looks terribly uncomfortable in his Ponce de Leon hat and buccaneer uniform. He rings up an order for an older Customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you in school, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to school in the mornings. I have a work study program for the afternoon. He bags one final coffee and punches up the amount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $8.46, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go. I have it exactly.  (sets money down) Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, and thanks for coming to Captain Kidd. Brad loosens his buccaneer scarf, and starts back towards the kitchen. He is stopped by the sudden appearance of Captain Kidd Assistant Manager, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton! I'll take over the fryer. Those boys at IBM need some Catch of-the-Day boxes, and I told them you would personally deliver them within the hour. I'll reimburse you for gas. Brad dutifully unhooks his apron, to reveal the bottom half of his pirate suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just write me out a bill. While Harold leans down to tally up the fish order, Brad goes to a nearby employee's closet. He has completely perfected the art of changing back into his street clothes, and it takes less than a minute. He is just about to finish buttoning his street shirt when Harold sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamilton, come over here. What is that you've got on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how I dress all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you took off your Captain Kidd uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd take it off for the drive over to IBM. It's kind of uncomfortable. Harold can barely fathom the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Hamilton. You're going over there to represent Captain Kidd Fish and Chips. We have stores all over Southern California. Part of our image, part of our appeal is in our uniforms. You know that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really want me to put all this stuff back on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I think so. Show some pride, Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: as he stands there, stoic looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you're asking me to do this, but okay. He begins taking off his street shirt. He looks at Harold, looks at the boxes, and returns to the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad is driving down the freeway, listening to the music of Bruce Springsteen's "Out in the Streets." He pries open one of the fourteen Catch-of-the-Day boxes on the seat next to him and pulls out a small piece of fried fish. Brad takes a bite. The look on his face says it is the worst piece of shit he has ever tasted. He throws the piece out the window, and drives on. Brad turns to see a girl smiling at him from another car. It makes his afternoon. He returns the smile with gusto.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL
dialogues.text: as she bursts out laughing and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: looking perplexed. Then he realizes that he hasn't taken his Ponce de Leon hat off. Brad drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as we see the Cruising Vessel move down the highway. We see the Captain Kidd hat go flying out the window. Then the plastic sword, and the scarf. Then a couple boxes of Captain Kidd fish. Then the rest of them. We see Brad rip past the IBM Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School is out and kids are leaving campus, heading for the parking lot and bus stop. We see Mike Damone carrying some books, walking towards Ridgemont Drive. He is joined by Stacy Hamilton, who hurries to catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait until I can drive next year. I walk every day. It's such a drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a ride with somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get a ride with my brother. But he usually works in the mornings, and then drives to school himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a guy.  Damone turns to her after a moment, all Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mark Ratner really likes you. You like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is a really nice boy... Stacy walks along, then stops and looks at Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I think I like you. They turn the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have arrived at Stacy's house. There are no cars parked out front. No one is home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to come in for a second? The Attitude starts to weaken. After a long pause, Damone responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any ice tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Come on in. Stacy unlocks her front door, they go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone stands in the white linoleum Hamilton kitchen. Stacy opens the refrigerator door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess the annuals are coming in pretty soon. Are you going to get one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you curious to see how your class picture turned out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I look like. Stacy places a glass of ice tea in front of him. They are all alone in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to take a quick swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad probably has some trunks you can borrow... I'm going to my room to change! Damone stares straight ahead. She's going to her room to change. Stacy scoots down the hall toward her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great ice tea!

dialogues.speaker: STACY IN HER ROOM
dialogues.text: In the middle of changing, she has caught her own reflection in the mirror. She pauses a moment, looking at the young girl looking back.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: He continues staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from other room) You don't have to shout! You can come back here to my room! Damone doesn't move. He pretends he doesn't hear. A moment later, Stacy comes bounding back down the hall in her green bikini. She grabs Damone by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me! I know there's a suit in the changing room! She pulls him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the wood-panelled changing room next to the Hamilton pool. There are two swimsuits hanging from wooden pegs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's getting pretty late... She locks the door to the changing room and begins to walk towards Mike Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really a virgin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... He could feel his leg starting to shake the slightest bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay if it's your first time. She gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. I feel pretty strange here. Because Mark really likes you, and he's my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my friend, too. She gives him another kiss. He kisses her in return. Standing there, feeling Stacy in her bikini, feeling her kiss him, Damone also felt some of his reservations slip away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a really good kisser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you. (pause) Are you shaking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking) No. Are you crazy? It is clear that this is as far as Mr. Attitude has ever gotten with a girl. Stacy takes the initiative, rubbing her hands through his hair, rubbing his sides, kissing his neck, then pulling away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Why don't you take off your clothes, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about both of us at the same time? Damone nods, and watches as Stacy unhooks her top and steps out of her bikini bottom. She stands naked in the shadows of the afternoon sun. She sits down naked on a red changing room couch, and gathers her legs up to her chest. She watches as Damone struggles with his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE
dialogues.text: hopping on one leg, pulling first out of his pants, then his jockey underwear. Bashfully, he goes to sit next to Stacy on the couch. They begin to kiss, and it quickly escalates into heavy petting. Stacy pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know that it's your final decision if we should continue or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's continue. Stacy leans back and pulls him on top of her. He enters her and begins pumping so hard, so fast, that he doesn't notice he's banging the sofa into the wall of the changing room. But just as quickly as Damone starts, he stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers) Hey, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're making a lot of noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. He has a strange look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I came. Didn't you feel it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I did. They lay there, Damone still on top of her on the red couch.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE
dialogues.text: as we read the confusion on his face. He is embarrassed, a little confused... mostly he just wants to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get home. I've really got to go, Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: as she looks up at him. She gives him a kiss. Damone gets up puts his pants and shirt on. He leaves the changing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Stacy sitting at her usual seat, and she's wearing a bright spring dress with a slight amount of makeup. She looks at Damone's seat with anticipation, but it remains empty as other students file in. Finally, she turns to The Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mike today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today's April 16th. Damone never comes to school on April 16th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's April 16th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's John Bonham's birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Bonham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Bonham. The drummer for Led Zeppelin. He died a couple years ago. Every birthday he stays home and plays everything John Bonham ever recorded. It's like his own holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. The bell rings, and Mr. Vargas enters the room with his Sanka cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at the desk is Mrs. O'Rourke. There is a knock at the door. The door swings open. Brad Hamilton holds out his yellow slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Brad... Brad have you got your list of college applications?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, to tell you the truth Mrs. O'Rourke, I've kind of been putting it off. I'm not sure what I want to do yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by rote) All right Brad. Let me ask you like this. If I were queen of the world, and I could make you whatever you wanted to be, what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Burt Reynolds. There is no humor on Mrs. O'Rourke's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize it's important to have fun in your senior year, with your friends, but there comes a time when you have to get serious about your future, think about college, and put aside all this fun. Brad looks up suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Mrs. O'Rourke? I broke up with my girlfriend this year. I lost my job at Carl's, and two other places. I wake up at 5:30 to work at 7-11, then I go to school, then I go back to 7-11. I have to pay rent, you know. My grades haven't been that bad, and now you're telling me that the fun is over. Well, I'm still waiting for the fun to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, I'll see you when I'm through with the rest of the seniors. If you want to visit the career office, go right ahead. I'll talk to you when you're more prepared. Brad gathers his books and opens the door to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next! An absolutely exuberant Cindy Carr pops her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-yeeeeeeee!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell has just rung, and Mike Damone comes out of Youth and Law class. He has an absorbed, driven look on his face. He walks past the rows of lockers, and doesn't even notice as he passes Stacy Hamilton standing by her locker. She smiles, grabs his arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Mike! Damone turns to see her, is thoroughly unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see you this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm kind of in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a hurry too. I just thought I could say hi to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. He pulls away, leaving a bewildered Stacy standing by her locker. She grabs some books and hurries in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up to the front entrance of University Hospital. The students file out and collect next to the front door. Mr. Vargas gleefully addresses the class. This is his favorite field trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today we're going to explore how this hospital works to preserve human life. We'll be visiting every floor, every level where these fine doctors and nurses take care of us, in life... and in death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class exits from a hospital elevator, onto another floor. They are now standing outside the maternity ward. We hear the loud noise of babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over thirty children are delivered here each day... The class moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class exits another hospital elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is part of your third quarter exam, and I'd advise you to take careful notes on what we're about to see.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MILLER
dialogues.text: a young intern who has joined the class for the last part of their tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I just ask you one last time to conduct yourselves with the utmost maturity... The kids are beginning to get very nervous now as they are led down the hall to the "Cold Room." The door to the "Cold Room" has only one sign on it. It reads: CADAVERS -- MEDICAL EXAMINATION ONLY. Mr. Vargas opens the door, and the class seems to gasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are six examination tables in the "Cold Room". Each of them contains a cadaver covered by a white sheet. Mr. Vargas has gathered the class around one table in particular. He fingers the edge of the white sheet as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, all the bodies in this room are recently deceased human bio-structures. A student raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Randy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of them were derelicts, Randy. They sold the right for medical examination of their bodies for money. Something like thirty dollars, I believe. Isn't that right, Doctor Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF SPICOLI
dialogues.text: who turns to Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five bucks is pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this gentleman here is named Arthur. Arthur died from heart failure last week and we are fortunate enough to view his body in its pristine state. Mr. Vargas suddenly pulls the white sheet aside and we see the body of Arthur. The students' eyes widen. Some gasp. Others cover their mouths. Others begin furious notes. Nobody speaks. The body of Arthur is smallish and withered. It is orange, flaky, and not quite real looking. A deep cut has been made in Arthur's chest. Mr. Vargas bends Arthur upright for a better student view. He gestures to the deep cut made in Arthur's chest. The tension mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This incision allows us to pull aside the skin covering of the chest cavity and really observe the human organs as they exist in their natural state.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: and his shrunken face, which seems to say please don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want all of you to take a look at the chest cavity for just a moment. Mr. Vargas grabs the two sides of Arthur's chest cavity covering, and rips it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we have the human lungs and heart, which you can see is actually located in the center of your chest. With a squish, Mr. Vargas reaches inside Arthur and pulls out the human heart for display. The class stands in silent shock. Only one comment escapes from any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitchin'.

dialogues.speaker: STACY HAMILTON
dialogues.text: who goes running out of the "Cold Room", holding her mouth. The Rat runs after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat and Stacy sit side-by-side on some orange plastic chairs, by a nurse's desk. Stacy is shook up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a fool of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody noticed. Don't worry about it. We'll just stay out here until everyone comes out, we'll blend back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the notes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you the notes. She squeezes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The students file out of the hospital, looking like they've just been through a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is night, and Linda and Stacy are watching Fantasy Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Tatoo, what this man doesn't realize is that he must one day leave Fantasy Island. And he must continue his life as an incurable leper. Stacy is fighting back tears. Linda looks angry. Telephone rings. Linda jumps to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Linda obviously is disappointed when she hears a female voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... you're kidding... What did he say... What did you say... How much did it cost? Look, tell him he can have a relationship with you or a 'more open' relationship with someone else... Listen, Debbie, can I call you later. I'm waiting for Doug to call. She plops back on the couch with Stacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet he forgets to call again. She notices that Stacy is crying over the TV show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Stacy, it's not that sad. It's just David Soul and Ricardo Montalban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm just so depressed. Everything is just so... depressing. Linda shuts off the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been acting very strange the last few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I just don't feel right. Linda sits down next to Stacy on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It couldn't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be. I had a pregnancy test at the clinic. I'll find out Monday. I guess it was Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it was Damone. If it was Ron Johnson, you'd be out to here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to tell him. He's an asshole. I hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it costs money to have an abortion. Even at the Free Clinic. You tell Damone to pay for it. It's the least he can do. It's the guy's responsibility too. She puts the TV back on and they watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there's one thing you didn't tell me about guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me that they can be so nice, so great... but then you sleep with them and they start acting like they're five years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I didn't tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy Hamilton is walking towards Mike Damone on the football field. We see him from a distance, timing track runners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike, there's something that's been on my mind and I have to tell you about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Now? He clicks off the time on a runner, and then turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you call me up tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike. I want you to know that I'm pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: as she looks down. They are words she never thought she would be speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know it's mine? We only did it once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE
dialogues.text: as he realizes she is sincere, and he truly begins to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made me do it! You locked the door. You made me do it! You wanted it more than me!

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: She does not flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I take it back.

dialogues.speaker: DAMONE
dialogues.text: He hugs his arms tighter across his chest, and decides to try a more mature tact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one thing we can do. We've got to get rid of it. We've got to get an abortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get an abortion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. My brother Art got his girlfriend one once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already planned, Mike. It's going to cost $150 at the Free Clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't sound free to me. (pause) So you want me to pay for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half. Okay? (bites back tears) Seventy-five dollars. And a ride to the clinic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-five dollars, and a ride. Okay. Stacy stands there, hands folded, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is working at his desk, counting through a wad of money.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIST
dialogues.text: in front of him, which has a split line down the middle. People Who Owe Me -- fifteen dollars Rick. People I Owe -seventy-five dollars REO Speedwagon tickets, seventy-five dollars abortion. Damone counts fifteen dollars into his stack, crosses out Rick. Then he counts through the money. Seventy five dollars exactly. He crosses out REO Speedwagon tickets. This leaves him no money for the abortion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, at the same corner where she once waited for Ron Johnson, Stacy waits for Damone. Cars pass, no Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy is on the phone, calling Damone. We see the phone messages sheet that lists two calls for Stacy, and none for Brad. The line rings four times, then it's answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... is Mike there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. Stacy sags, disbelieving, and looks at the clock on the kitchen wall. It's getting late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he's helping his father in the garage and he'll call you back. Stacy is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Stacy hangs up. She punches out another number, quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Barrett. Is Linda there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She went off to the beach. She'll be back later, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks. She looks at the clock again, then hears a noise in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad! Hey, wait a second! She runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad and Stacy pull up next to the flea market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is it. I have some shopping to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, Brad. I really appreciate it. She gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy Hamilton watches her brother drive away. Then she looks to both sides, and walks on. She passes the entrance to the Flea Market. She walks around the corner to another building marked BIRTH CONTROL - FREE CLINIC. Brad follows her in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy is lying in bed wearing a paper dress. Her hair is stuffed in paper shower cap. She looks anxious. In a bed next to her an older girl is being affectionate with her visiting boyfriend. A Nurse comes in with an IV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to prick a little. She sticks the needle into Stacy's hand. Stacy looks pained but doesn't yell. The Nurse pats the rolling bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now scoot over here. Stacy moves onto it. Looking up from her point of view, we see the ride out of the room and into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy gets wheeled in. The Doctor looks down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Stacy, I'm Doctor Bartell. Stacy moves onto the operating table as the Nurse and Doctor get ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions before we begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going to hurt, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll use a local but you'll feel some pressure. It doesn't last that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it hurt more to have a baby? The Doctor pauses and considers her question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... but I think you mind it less. Stacy looks up at the lights and listens to the sound of suction tubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other girl and Stacy sit at a table eating toast and jelly. The girl is reading. The Nurse enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we doing in here? Debbie, ready to leave? The girl nods and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right through here. Stacy, I can't let you go unless you have a ride home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, my boyfriend said held be waiting downstairs. The Nurse studies her, decides she's telling the truth and allows her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy walks back out into the sunlight, slowly and weakly. She is surprised and amazed at who she sees standing outside, waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD HAMILTON
dialogues.text: He stands, hands on hips, just outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad! He puts an arm around her and leads her toward his waiting car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you shop at the Flea Market anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad. Please don't tell Mom and Dad... He helps her into the cruising vessel. He starts up the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did it? Stacy stares out the window. Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to tell me, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then. It's your secret. Stacy smiles at Brad. Brad smiles back. The car drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy is in Linda's room, sitting on her bed. Her eyes are red and moist from crying. Linda listens to her story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really thought he would show up. I waited... and waited... and waited...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I called his house, and his mother told me he was in the garage helping his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid for it and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes your stereo for another year. Mike Damone is a no-brain little prick. I'm not letting him get away with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do anything, Linda. I'd rather just forget about it. I don't even like the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy, he's not a guy.  (loud) He's a little prick!  Stacy lies back on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door to the Damone house opens, and out walks Mike Damone carrying some books. He looks troubled, burdened, and stares down at the walkway as he moves towards his car. He walks around, starts to pen the car door, then he sees it. There, in white spray paint across the driver's door, is the message: PRICK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhhhhhhit. He looks both ways, and starts back towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Damone travels down Ridgemont Drive, making the turn into the school parking lot. There is a large cardboard panel taped on the side of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arrives at his locker, where, in white spray paint, there is another message: LITTLE PRICK. Several girls walk by, they laugh knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, mike! Damone backs up against the locker, with a sick smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... girls. More students pass, looking strangely at the young man pinned against his own locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone exits the boys locker room. Just as he does, he is accosted by The Rat. We have never quite heard this tone in The Rat's voice before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damone? What happened between you and Stacy? Damone feigns The Attitude, shakes his head. Damone sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something, Rat. Sometimes girls just go haywire. It was a month ago, I've been trying to think of a way to tell you ever since. We started messing around and...  (shrugs) ... something happened. It's all over with. It's no big deal. I never called her again. The Rat says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me, she's pretty aggressive. You understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Damone. I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't really your girlfriend anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey fuck you Damone. There's a lot of girls out there and you mess around with Stacy. What have you got to prove?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always stick up for you. Whenever people say 'Aw, that Damone is a loudmouth' -- and they say that a lot -- I say 'You just don't know Damone.' When someone says you're an idiot, I tell them 'Damone's not an idiot. You just don't know him.' Well, you know, Damone, maybe they do know you pretty good. And I'm just finding out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Get lost. Damone starts to push past him, but The Rat shoves his shoulder hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Rat. You want to do something about it? Damone begins the classic high school fighting ritual. He throws his books down. He takes a step back. He goes into a crouch. He gestures towards himself. Then Damone says the universally recognized high school fighting words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well come on. The Rat shows no fear. As other kids begin to crowd around the two boys, Rat throws his own books down. He takes a step back, goes into the crouch. He gestures toward himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come on. They stand there, gesturing, neither one of them wanting to make the first move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You come on, you wuss. Assistant Coach Mr. Sexton comes running out of the boy's locker room, and steps in front of the two boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Knock this crap off!! The Rat stalks off, disappearing into the crowd of onlookers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ridgemont Drive strip is filled with cars, cruising for parties. There is a lot of honking, and yelling out windows. Everyone is headed towards the beach. We stay on a lowly 7-11 store near the freeway entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A yellow Firebird slowly, menacingly cruises the empty parking lot. It does not stop. Then, around the corner, walks Jeff Spicoli. We see him in the neon 7-11 light, his hands stuffed deep into the pockets of baggy jeans. He walks inside the store. He is the only shopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad Hamilton stands behind the counter in a red and white striped shirt and cap, making fresh coffee. Jeff Spicoli trudges up to the counter. He looks at Brad. Brad looks at Spicoli. There is an unspoken edge between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mon, can I use the bathroom? Brad squints his eyes, looks at the sign on the back room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sign which reads: Rest Room For Employees Only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Just make it quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first door on your left. Spicoli disappears into the back room. Brad sighs, looks at the clock. It reads: 11:15. Then he hears Spicoli from the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find it, mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first door on your left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ledge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First door on your left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is! Brad sighs again. He loads a new filter into the coffee maker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment later, the yellow Firebird pulls into the 7-11 parking lot. A man in a windbreaker comes hurtling out of the car, into the store. He spray paints the scanning camera above the door. He hustles up to the counter, produces a .45 Magnum and points it chest high at Brad. There is a glazed and nervous speedy edge to his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want money. And I want it all -- now. Brad looks pale and young under the fluorescent 7 11 light. He speaks slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They empty and close the big safe here at midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting tougher) I know this store. I know where the safe is. He bangs the gun on the counter, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there behind the donut case. Now move! Brad slowly moves to the donut case, like a zombie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm instructed to tell you that we are on a video alarm system and there are other hidden cameras in the store ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me the money. Move it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (legs are shaking) I just started here, and they just taught me the procedure. I'll give you the money, just let me figure this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very menacing) Move it. Move it. Brad opens the phony back of the donut case and fiddles with the strongbox combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more menacing) Let's go, stupid. Brad looks at the gunman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You motherfucker. Get off my fuckin' case. The Robber is about to react when the bathroom door opens and Jeff Spicoli starts out, wiping his hands on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No towels, mon... The Robber turns to look at Spicoli, and that is all that Brad Hamilton needs. Just like it is the most natural thing in the world, Brad reaches for the hot, steaming coffee pot he has just made and throws it into the gunman's face and hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaarrrrrrrrr!!! The .45 falls out of his hand and rattles to the floor. The gunman is still grabbing his face, and looking at his skinless hands in horror when Brad snaps up the gun. In the parking lot, the gunman's accomplice, poised behind the wheel of the yellow Firebird, spots the foul-up and screeches out of the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There goes your ride home. Brad pulls the under-counter alarm with newfound confidence. Jeff Spicoli stands there, mesmerized at the entire event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome. Totally awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are pouring into the Ridgemont mall. Summer banners are already up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the midst of all the kids and shoppers, we see The Rat walking slowly down the promenade. He is wearing an Army surplus jacket, and his hands are buried deep in his pockets.  Two girls pass his way. One smiles briefly at him, and The Rat turns to watch her pass. He is about to say something to her, then no. He walks on, sees Swenson's Ice-Cream Parlor up ahead. The Rat decides to walk the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is busy again, filled with shoppers and teenagers in summer-type clothing. We see Stacy Hamilton, once again, at the cash register wearing an Assistant manager name tag and a hostess gown. She handles a customer's bill, then stands there a moment, looking glum. Linda Barrett approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another summer of working at Swenson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. There's lots of men around here. Keep your eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Linda. I've finally figured it out. It's not sex I want. Anyone can have sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want romance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romance in Ridgemont? We don't even get cable TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the back kitchen door, which swings open, and out comes Mike Damone in a peppermint Swenson's shirt. He wipes some grime on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike! You have a mess on C-9!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. All right. I just cleaned B-8. Give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get going. The two girls smile, go back to their posts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Spicoli sits in his room, and it is his castle. Clothes lie in disarray on the floor. A huge half-waxed surfboard is propped against the window. We see Spicoli dressed in a too large white short-sleeved shirt, attempting to tie his father's fat paisley tie. He stops to take a hit from his bong, all the while talking on the phone. The music of Lynyrd Skynyrd's "Freebird" plays on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... am... so... wasted, mon. What is in this shit? (pause) Doesn't that stuff cause brain damage? (pause) Bitchin'. Spicoli listens for a moment. He rubs his eyes, shakes his head. He is really buzzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mon, I am going to Mexico as soon as school is out. Two more weeks, bud. Week from Wednesday. (pause) I am gonna take both boards, my duck feet, many cases of beer, and just jam. (pause) No, mon, from school. I'm leaving as soon as school gets out. I'll be at Sunset Cliffs by nighttime. (pause) Totally. (pause) Later. Spicoli hangs up, and concentrates on tying his tie. He almost strangles himself. Then suddenly the door to his room flies open and Spicoli's little brother Curtis bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff you have company!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, Curtis. If you can't knock, I can't hear you. Curtis slams the door and leaves. A moment later there is a knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better. Come in. The door swings open and Jeff Spicoli sits in stoned shock at the sight before him. There, standing in the doorway of his room is Mr. Hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr... Mr. Hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Jeff. Mind if I come in? Spicoli can only nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling downstairs) Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Spicoli. Hand walks into Spicoli's room, takes off his suit jacket and lays it on the chair back. He stops a moment and catches the stare of Miss January Penthouse on the wall, then turns to Spicoli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you going somewhere tonight, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Graduation Dance Mr. Hand. It's the last school event of the year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we've got some things to discuss here, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I do something wrong, Mr. Hand? Hand removes several copies of Oui Magazine from another chair and sits down. He sets his briefcase on Spicoli's dresser, next to a bag of pot, and opens it up for easy access.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to sit there, Jeff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. You sit right here on your bed. I'll use the chair here.  (pause) As I explained to your parents just a moment ago, and to you many times since the very beginning of the school year -- I don't like to spend my time waiting for late students, or detention cases. I'd rather be preparing the lesson. Mr. Hand takes a sheet from his briefcase and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to my calculations, Mr. Spicoli, you wasted a total of eight hours of my time this year. And rest assured that is a kind estimate. He returns the sheet to his case and looks into Spicoli's weed-ravaged eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Spicoli, comes a rare moment for me. Now I have the unique pleasure of squaring our account. Tonight, you and I are going to talk in great detail about the Davis Agreement, all the associated treaties, and the American Revolution in particular. Now if you can just turn to Chapter 47 of Lord of Truth And Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's in my locker, Mr. Hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, I'm glad I remembered to bring an extra copy just for you. Hand reaches in his case and produces the book. He hands it to Spicoli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearily, Spicoli is trying to grasp the material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so, like, when Jefferson went before the people what he was saying was 'Hey, we left this place in England because it was bogus, and if we don't come up with some cool rules ourself, we'll be bogus, too!' Right?

dialogues.speaker: MR. HAND
dialogues.text: who nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very close, Jeff. Hand reaches over and gets his case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've made my point with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Hand, can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a guy like me every year? A guy to... I don't know, make a show of. Teach other kids lessons and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'll find out next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) No way, mon. When I graduate U.S. history I ain't even coming over to your side of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you graduate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicked) You're gonna flunk me?! Mr. Hand pauses a moment, then breaks into the nearest approximation of a grin we have seen all year. It isn't much, but it's noticeable. His lips crinkle at the ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Spicoli. You'll probably squeak by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Oh, yeah! Mr. Hand has now gathered all his material, and he stands to approach Spicoli's door. Jeff jumps up, extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha, Mr. Hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha, Spicoli. Mr. Hand exits the room, and descends the staircase of the Spicoli household. Spicoli kicks the door shut, grins, and continues struggling with his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight angle on the emotion-filled face of the lead singer in a cheesy high school band called the T Birds. He is bathed in a blue light, singing the last verse of The Eagles' 'Take It To The Limit'. We pull back to reveal a large, clumsy banner reading: LAST DANCE. Students are pouring into the gym for this event. Many have brought their annual yearbooks. On stage, the lead singer snaps his fingers and the band goes into Nick Lowe's 'Heart of the City'. Some students start to dance. Every one of our characters is either here, or about to arrive. From Charles Jefferson to Spicoli to Mr. Hand. For once, all classes are partying together. But, just as in the beginning of the year on lunch court, the kids are still cordoned off into their distinctive cliques.

dialogues.speaker: MORE STUDENTS ARRIVING
dialogues.text: at the Last Dance. They see Mr. Hand signing annuals by the door. They all say the same thing as they pass, "Aloha, Mr. Hand". He nods in return.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: surveying the growing mob of annual-crazed students. From behind her comes Linda Barrett in a low-cut black dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not coming? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he's got to stay in Chicago. (sighs) He says I should visit him sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, like maybe never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I might go to Dartmouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dartmouth?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't tell anyone I applied cause I never thought I'd make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it! But what about Doug?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a world of guys out there. I just wish I didn't have to date any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- Doug Stallworth? It's his loss.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE DAMONE
dialogues.text: in another part of the dance, by the Junior class sponsored food counter. Damone is standing, talking to several girls, gesturing and being Damone, Mr. Attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign my annual, honey.  The girls look at each other, laugh. They walk away.

dialogues.speaker: THE RAT
dialogues.text: standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're losing it, Damone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Those girls love me.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF SPICOLI
dialogues.text: sprawled out in the bleachers with his surfer stoner buddies. He turns to one admiring stoner (Todd).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mon. Sign my annual. Spicoli slips the annual into the kid's crotch. The stoner winces in pain, but still opens the book and lingers on all the signings in Spicoli's annual. They are all drug-related messages from fellow stoners. After a moment, Spicoli's friend signs: "Thanks for the reds. Todd."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mon, good thing we're going to Mexico this summer. 'Cause you're gonna get kicked out of your house when your parents read your annual.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Brad Hamilton pushes both doors open, and makes his entrance into the Last Dance. There is a lot of activity going on, but all nearby eyes turn to Brad as he walks into the dance. Fifteen kids immediately gravitate towards him. They all want Brad to sign their annuals, to talk about the 7-11 incident. Onstage, the T-Birds play the Beatles' "It Won't Be Long". We see Brad's old girlfriend Lisa push up to him. Her new jock boyfriend holds a protective arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your picture in the paper. You had the greatest look on your face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front of the Metro Section. I'm telling my parents, 'I know this guy, I know this guy.' Lisa's boyfriend pulls his arm tighter around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign my annual, Brad? Brad smiles, nods. He signs, and gives her his. We then see Brad's three Buddies from Carl's Jr. come up, pat him on the back and grab his shoulder. Brad studies them warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' manager of 7-11!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get us jobs over there, Brad! You can do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do you guys want to work at 7-11?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Brad! It would be great! All of us together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, 7-11 is a tremendous operation. It's really changed, man. They've got great food, great magazines, videogames... it's class. Total class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as you can get us in there, we're gone from Carl's, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man, all the little punks from junior high have taken over the place. Brad leaves his old buddies. He grins and notices someone across the crowded dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
